awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF award will provide partial support for the U.S. based participants of the "Young Geometric Group Theory XI" conference, which will be held in Münster, Germany, February 13-17, 2023. This international conference series is primarily aimed at graduate students and early career researchers working in geometric group theory and related areas of mathematics. The aim of the conference is to expose these researchers to new topics, to provide them with an opportunity to present their work, and to facilitate collaborations. The meeting includes mini-courses by established experts, plenary talks by selected early career researchers, informal discussion sessions, lightning talks by participants, a poster session, and two panels. The mini-courses are on topics at the forefront of research in geometric group theory. The panels will focus on professional development as well as on equity, diversity, and inclusion.

The mini-courses in this conferences are Big Mapping Class Groups by Federica Fanoni, Cannon-Thurston Maps by Mahan Mj, Soficity by Andreas Thom, and Incoherence and Quasiconvexity by Genevieve Walsh. These lectures will present a panoramic overview of some of the important developments in their field. The plenary presentations will aim to focus on other recent research and directions to broaden the scope of the workshop, and to encourage the participants to explore the boundaries of the subject. More information about the conference can be found on the conference website: https://www.uni-muenster.de/GGT/YGGT/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The workshop "Young Geometric Group Theory XI" (YGGT XI) took place at the University of Münster in Germany on February 13 - 17, 2023. YGGT is an annual conference for early career researchers, mostly graduate students, working in geometric group theory and related fields. The 2023 attracted a lot of interest from potential attendees, of which 160 were accepted to attend. This grant partially supported 26 participants, all either graduate students or postdocs at institutions in the US. Majority of the supported participants belong to the groups underrepresented in MPS.

The main activities at the workshop were three mini-courses, seven plenary talks by junior researchers, discussion sessions, two panels, a lightning talk session, and a poster session. The mini-courses were given by Mahan Mj (Tata Institute of Fundamental Research), Andreas Thom (Technische Universität Dresden), and Genevieve Walsh (Tufts University). The plenary talks were given by Michelle Chu (University of Minnesota), Sam Hughes (University of Oxford), Annette Karrer (McGill University), Rylee Lyman (Rutgers University), Jean-Pierre Mutanguha (Princeton University), Stephan Stadler (MPI-Bonn), and Ignacio Vergara (Universidad de Santiago de Chile). In the daily discussion sessions attendees could request further explanations of the content of the mini courses or introductions to other topics. The lightning talk and poster sessions provided opportunity for the attendees to advertise their own work.

The workshop was organized with the support by the Cluster of Excellence Mathematics Münster, the German Research Foundation (DFG) by means of the Priority Program 2026 'Geometry at Infinity', and the Research Training Group 2297 'MathCoRe' in Magdeburg, as well as the NSF. The future editions of YGGT are planned to take place in Bristol, UK in 2024, and Copenhagen, Denmark in 2025.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 03/29/2024
Modified by: Katarzyna Jankiewicz
